128123122.reviewBody: Absolutely beautiful protected area.  A photographer\'s dream!

127546095.name: One of the World\'s natural wonders
127546095.author: a TripAdvisor user
127546095.reviewBody: We just spent the better part of 10 days in Loreto and were able to visit a number of the islands which comprise the National Park. They were all wonderful, but we secially like Isla Coronados and it\'s perfect white sand beaches with the red stone mountains as a backdrop it is wonderful. We also visited Isla Carmen and the Bay of Balandras where we went snorkelling for clams and scallops, absolutely fantastic and the prize was  a fabulous fresh treasure for lunch. \nThe Bay of Loreto is, as we were told, the place where the mountains come to swim and that has to be the right metaphor, we are not sure what was better, the water and all its wonders or the mountains and the ruggedness of the views.\nWhatever we choose, this is a place to have on anyone\'s bucket list!

127083357.name: Great scenery
127083357.author: a TripAdvisor user
127083357.reviewBody: Kayaking and paddle boarding without the jet ski\'s and parasails found at other Mexican beach resorts

126942800.name: not everybody is aware that the bay is a National Park
126942800.author: a TripAdvisor user
126942800.reviewBody: Beautiful environment, peaceful place with very nice and divers locations for beach and underwater activities.

126750005.name: Extraordinary Baja
126750005.author: a TripAdvisor user
126750005.reviewBody: 20-minute boat ride to deserted islands with white sandy beaches and emerald green water, the desert mountains giving the whole scene a surreal moonscape aura...on the water in boats...snorkel, dive, swim, feel one with the whales, dolphins, sea lions, birds, fish and the deep blue sea. Makes you wonder what buildings, SUV\'s and freeways have to do with anything!

126421177.name: Isla Coronados Kayak Camping Trip
126421177.author: a TripAdvisor user
126421177.reviewBody: Checked in first with the Parque Nacional in the marina, paid the minimal entry fee ($28 pesos/day pp I think), selected our campsite, and then kayaked out to Isla Coronados for a two day camping trip.  We chose site 6 to be within a short walk to the toilets and palapas in site 5.  Site 6 has its own beach and is well protected from north winds.  The very pretty site 7 is less protected and the shallow site 3 is completely open to the north.  A few pangas came to site 5 during the day but each night we had the whole island to ourselves.  Kayaked around the island to see the sea lions on the north shore.  Beautiful sunsets over the Baja west coast.  Snorkeling (with wet suits) was rewarding around the rock island just offshore to the south.

126288523.name: kayak trip
126288523.author: a TripAdvisor user
126288523.reviewBody: Nice place to kayak and see the fish and wildlife. Not many boats at all.\nYou should make sure it isn\'t going to be windy later in the day before you head out in the morning.

125867679.name: Care for the Environment
125867679.author: a TripAdvisor user
125867679.reviewBody: The local people and tour companies seem to take great pride and care with the National Marine Park

125800412.name: Great conservation
125800412.author: a TripAdvisor user
125800412.reviewBody: Loved the dolphiins! and sealions and cormorants and pelicans and osprey

125157214.name: Warm, lovely Sea of Cortes
125157214.author: a TripAdvisor user
125157214.reviewBody: The five Islands have best sandy beaches for snorkeling, whale watching and enjoying the day.

124828655.name: Playing with the Whales
124828655.author: a TripAdvisor user
124828655.reviewBody: We actually were able to touch the whates and watch the mothers teach their young to interact with humans.

123893355.name: paddling from Villa del Mar
123893355.author: a TripAdvisor user
123893355.reviewBody: used their kayaks, paddled 2 1/2 hours and went for a swim

122499718.name: Cold water!
122499718.author: a TripAdvisor user
122499718.reviewBody: We did enjoy seeing dolphins and lots of colorful fish but the water was REALLY cold!

121701830.name: Eco-minded Citizenry!
121701830.author: a TripAdvisor user
121701830.reviewBody: Loreto boasts being the most ecologically-minded town in all of Mexico, and it seems to be. Visit the Eco-Alianza office in the town to learn more about how concerned residents are raising awareness and protecting important species, such as sea turtles!

120601919.name: fun
120601919.author: a TripAdvisor user
120601919.reviewBody: jill and Rick can help you book personable reliable boats and guides to cruise, snorkell kayak the island in the marine park

61223275.name: 1000 bottlenose Dolphins!
61223275.author: a TripAdvisor user
61223275.reviewBody: Our day was lead by our great fising guide from Arturo\'s Sportfishing and he treated us well!  Our captain knew what he was doing.  We caught 6 yellowtail tuna in the morning.  In the cold water they fought like crazy.  My wife just about got pulled overboard!  Other highlights of the day were seeing a pod of probably 1000 bottlenose dolphins, a couple of blue whales (they are HUUUUGE!!), a couple of marlin finning on the surface, a flock of pelicans flying in perfect formation. \n\nAmazing

674263356.name: Beautiful Old Mission and well worth seeing
674263356.author: a TripAdvisor user
674263356.reviewBody: This was a wonderful Mission and enjoyed seeing and reading out the Mission, seeing the grounds and enjoying the day. Well worth the tour to see it.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

670016018.name: Functioning Mission
670016018.author: a TripAdvisor user
670016018.reviewBody: This mission is located down a winding  road with scenic mountains along the way. Take time to stop at the lookouts. There\u2019s a combination of dry and then the surprise of palm trees at the base of the valley. The mission itself is a functioning church. When we were there they had a vacation  bible school going on. They charge for the museum, only go in if you are functional in Spanish. The walk to the oldest all of tree is to the right behind the church. There is a man that collects a few pesos to view the tree. There are restaurants and a few shops. They also make local wine from the grapes they have there.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

668775300.name: Wonderful slice of history
668775300.author: a TripAdvisor user
668775300.reviewBody: A 45 minute drive to an old Mission at an oasis in the rugged mountains above Loreto led to an interesting visit to a stellar building constructed in 1699. Why on Earth would someone build there of all places? Never mind, it is a fantastic site recalling the age of Spanish and Catholic imperialism. A stellar achievement that has lasted over 300 years. We ate lunch at the Palapa restaurant there and it was ok as fuel, but not special. The old Olive tree in the back was a highlight for us as was the setting.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

667630038.name: A must for history buffs
667630038.author: a TripAdvisor user

666364520.name: Beautiful
666364520.author: a TripAdvisor user
666364520.reviewBody: The Mission is beautiful and well preserved.  It amazes me how they constructed such a wonderful place with such little resources high up into a mountain draw. The Mission caretaker speaks some English so he can give you great information about the Mission.  The guide who tooks us on a tour to the olive tree did not.  I was fortunate, a beautiful young Mexican girl translated for me. ( I was the only non Spanish speaking person on the tour).

650969610.name: A must visit into the past
650969610.author: a TripAdvisor user
650969610.reviewBody: Taking a break from the wonderful fishing experience that is Baja, we decided to take a day trip to the Javier Mission, high in the Sierra de la Giganta Mountains. What a treat! It was like seeing an old west movie set. There was nothing artificial here. Just a quiet  agrarian village of about 200 people. I was entranced by the way the water reaches the gardens. I could live this way.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

649221524.name: More than just the incredible buildings.
649221524.author: a TripAdvisor user
649221524.reviewBody: The drive from Loreto to the mission was quite interesting, passing parts of the course of the Baja 1000 off-road race, private ranches, a small chapel at Rancho Las Parras, palm canyons, and old fig trees that "tap" vertically for 20 to 40 feet, with lateral roots latching onto rocks for stability, all to garner any moisture they can get in this parched landscape. The strong desire to survive was totally awe-inspiring. \nThe mission itself was amazing, but we were equally impressed by the efforts of the early Jesuits to survive and sustain themselves here. There were extensive olive orchards and other fruit and cultivated gardens, fed by an ingenious system of canals using gravity to deliver water from a nearby river to the fields and households, and reservoirs that store water for irrigation. Definitely worth a visit. \nSight-seeing companies in Loreto offered tours to SJ at US$69 per person. My husband and I decided to be adventurous and hired the resourceful taxi that followed us to our hotel and offered to take us there. The taxi had a company logo and phone number, and the driver was in uniform, with his name on the shirt. We felt pretty safe, but we took photos of both with our iPhone for our record, just in case. The driver spoke sufficiently good English, and knew the sights along the way as well as about San Javier, so we had a wonderful 4- hour tour for 1000 pesos (about $55). We liked the driver so much we asked him to take us to the airport a few days later! The lunch at the Palapa restaurant at St Javier was quite good.

634468375.name: Historic and ecologically intriquing high mountain desert daytrip
634468375.author: a TripAdvisor user
634468375.reviewBody:
This was our 2nd visit in the past 7 years to this mountain valley marvel, 25 miles southeast of Loreto.  Our tour guide, Necky, from Desert Expeditions and Sea, was extremely knowledgeable providing insights not gleaned during our previous trip. 
What all of the pictures of The San Javier Mision and vistas from the scenic,  now fully paved, road to this hidden treasure fail to portray is  how the early missionaries let alone native peoples were able to utilize unique plants/trees and scattered oases to thrive in this harsh environment.  Old orchards/ olive tree and citrus and small farm plots surround the church connected by a still functioning aquduct system.

So don't ignore the ecologic features while viewing the magnificant, well preserved, still functioning, Jesuit ~300 year old architectural marvel.

588363232.author: a TripAdvisor user
588363232.reviewBody:

We didn't bring a map with us and there was no cell phone service so make sure you're prepared ahead of time. The mission is well worth the trek, however. It's well taken care of. Our makeshift guide took us through the mission, the grounds and gave us a short history tour. This was definitely a highlight of our Loreto trip. Not to be missed.

583460486.name: Chain of California Spanish Mission Began Here
583460486.author: a TripAdvisor user
583460486.reviewBody:
If you're interested in the history of the California and especially early Spanish Mission history, I think you'll enjoy visiting this Mission.

The building dates from about 1697 and as southern California residents, we're accustomed to living near the mission in San Juan Capistrano and visiting other California missions, but this one is special.

The ride up to the mountain is very interesting. Just when you think you're in the middle of Nowhere, you come across a small ranch, with cattle and goats. In spite of the arid climate, local ranchers up in the mountains manage to raise livestock and incredibly, fruit orchards!

There is the tiniest of pueblos surrounding the Mission. 

It's an interesting place to visit.

568991318.name: Wow, what an amazing place!
568991318.author: a TripAdvisor user
568991318.reviewBody:
Mission San Francisco, which is about a 45 minute drive from Loreto is a day trip that nobody should miss. The mission is the first mission ever built in Baja Mexico and has maintained in structural integrity for more than a century and a half.

The road that goes to the mission is now paved, so it is more comfortable and it takes less time to get there. The mission is beautiful. If you are a photographer, it's a dream to photograph. There are details, both in and out that are eye catching. I spent almost four hours photographing it. 

Although the mission in Loreto is nice, this mission is much better. In fact, the drive to the mission is an adventure in itself.

Definitely a place to visit when down in the Loreto area.

554951116.name: Worth it
554951116.author: a TripAdvisor user
554951116.reviewBody: Taxi drivers and tour groups wanted too much$ and we like to explore on our own so we rented a car and drove the 34k trip with another couple.  As others have already said, the drive itself is worth it.  Beautiful views and rugged terrain.  Paved road can be dangerous so do NOT rubber neck too much.  Hazzards include major holes at the edge of the road that can swallow a small car and which are unmarked dangers.  No shoulders on the road in most places.  Open range cattle grazing so expect critters standing in or next to road.  No traffic to worry with so take your time and use the pull overs.  Enjoy the journey, but drive it in daylight only to be safe (road hazards).  Falling rocks are a real and continuous danger!  The mission is a nice one hour walk around but be sure to visit the area behind it with the old olive trees, cisterns, terraced fields and grounds.  Read the history of the mission (on-line sources) before going so you better appreciate the experience.   The mission is a shrine so show respect and keep children under control please.  Buy the "coyota" pastry on sale by the locals under trees beside the mission.  About 50 cents and you will love them!  The village that surrounds the mission has been spared much of what is not to like in lowland MX.  They live quietly without crime and do not overpower tourists with stalls filled with trinkets.  Good trip with friends, children or couples.  Enjoy the drive (about an hour each way), just be vigilant!

552623188.name: Don\u2019t miss this secret hideaway
552623188.author: a TripAdvisor user
552623188.reviewBody: I can describe this place in one word: Incredible! The mission is an hour\u2019s drive from Loreto, through windy roads that keep climbing without ever reaching the top of the picturesque mountains in the south of Baja. The journey is breathtaking. You will marvel at its beauty. The 400-year-old mission is exquisite and stands proud. It is truly remarkable. It has been preserved in nearly pristine condition for four centuries, which, in my book, is something to celebrate. The mission contains a cemetery whose residents were laid to rest more than 100 years ago. Antique hand-forged one-of-a-kind crosses made by Mexican artisans adorn the gravesites. The mission is the showpiece within a tiny village of 72 people, all of whom had been off the grid for generations, before electricity began powering the village just ten years ago. Jorge manages the mission. He speaks passionately about the mission and is able to answer all questions about its history. I gave him a 100 peso tip and wish I had had more to give him. He is a knowledgeable docent and well worth tipping. Jorge speaks Spanish exclusively.   A five minute walk from the mission takes you to Sergio\u2019s private olive tree farm, where there is an enormous 400 plus year-old olive tree. The tree is older than the 17th century mission. The 100 peso fee (about five dollars) Sergio extracts for seeing his farm is money well spent. It allows you to see a unique business operation and ancient tree while helping to support an entrepreneur in a very poor and remote village. Sergio speaks Spanish but knows a few spattering zwords of English. A vendor, whose name I unfortunately forget, sells fantastic home-made guava sugar cookies for a mere 30 pesos for a bag containing two huge cookies. I bought three bags. The villagers keep their place on Earth in immaculate condition. It is spotless. Bring pesos. You will be glad to have them, as they will allow you to support the endeavors of the people who are striving to eke out an honest living in a very poor and remote mountain region. By the way, it costs five pesos to use the only bathroom that is available. What I want to say most about Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge Biaundo is Don\u2019t Miss It! This is a unique experience that will take you back in time while allowing you to experience unsurpassed natural beauty.

548464242.name: True history in Mexico
548464242.author: a TripAdvisor user
548464242.reviewBody: We visited during the Fiesta de San Javier December 1-3, 2017 Beginning early in the morning early, dozens upon dozens of riders gather on their horses in front of the Mission in Loreto where the priest comes out and blesses the riders and their mounts. A lively Mexican band starts up and the long 34 km ride to Mision San Javier begins. During this three day fiesta, thousands of pilgrims from all over Mexico arrive to participate and visit the cathedral with its 6 foot thick stone walls and gilded wall behind the altar.\n\nThe drive alone is worth while as the narrow road twist its way up into the rugged Sierra Giganta mountains, past ranches and surprising fresh water streams and pools. Along the way there are several oasis where everything oranges, citrus fruits and veggies grow on the ranchos. There are certain points along the way where you can look back out to the desert and Sea of Cortez from the mountain altitudes....

528119841.reviewBody: For those who are history buffs, this is the real deal. The Mission is either 200 or 300 years old; maybe late 1700s. Was among the first Mission Churches on the Baja peninsula. 499926174.name: The Winding Road to The 2nd of the California missions
499926174.author: a TripAdvisor user
499926174.reviewBody: Enjoy the winding road and just take it easy -- 99% of it is paved beautifully; where erosion and repairs are taking place, the workers return greetings and a wave as you pass.  The reward for the steep climb and sharp corners is the understated beauty of La Mision. A guide will describe the church while you embrace the surprisingly well preserved architecture. Armando then took me for a 30 minute tour of the 400 year old olive tree, his farm, then a short hike/climb for a vista overlooking the green valley and church.  The climb is steep, rocky, and narrow; seniors may not enjoy parts of it; just turn around and enjoy a mango while you wait for the others. This is a great 3 hour excursion; oh, and eat across the street at the Palapa!

478692023.name: Old Baja History
478692023.author: a TripAdvisor user
478692023.reviewBody:
Quite a pleasant 35km drive from coast to mountain valley. Mission San Javier represents some of the earliest Spanish history of Baja California. The history itself is not collectively in one spot and must be pieced together, but worth knowing. 
The mission is located in stark but well watered mountain valley where the Jesuits found indigenous people to convert. They added extensive irrigation and agriculture that can still be seen 400 years later.. 
A small plaza accompanies the Mission these days with food and limited shopping but quiet and slow moving ambiance make it a very enjoyable outing. 
The road is very good getting you to the Mission, but it shows signs of tremendous water events eroding a couple sections and making roadsides tenuous in places. Road work seems good at keeping road open and fixing issues.

473293226.author: a TripAdvisor user
473293226.reviewBody:
Ok, our hotel quoted $700 dollars to take us up for a day tour. We had our own van, but for $700 we could have rented a van and kept it for a week. 

So, if you have a car or a van, drive yourself up. If you don't, and want to go, then rent a car. Way cheaper. 

Use Google Maps to find the way. The day we drove up there had been an earthquake earlier in the day. A few small rocks on the road from the sides of mountains. There were a few rivers on the road. No big deal. 

The Mission looks bigger in pictures. It was very nice and rustic. Spent some time walking around. There are some shops and restaurants and a bathroom (costs $5 pesos. Worth it.) 

Nice little community and was a fun drive.

The mission is well maintained and preserved and a local resident who speaks reasonably good English will give you a tour with history for a few peso donation to the church. The art work and alter are simplistically beautiful and the grounds are worth the short walk around the exterior. There is a road side stand across the street from the mission to enjoy a cold beverage or basic food but there is no restaurant in town so don\'t plan on eating there. The drive in is a winding road that had a little construction going on when we visited in Feb 17. During the drive you are treated to lovely views of the surrounding landscape. itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

464743742.name: Mission San Javier

I was shocked that we were in a desert based off of the beautiful mountain scenery and streams.  Second, we were impressed with the small town at the top and the rich history. 462120352.name: Magical place in the Sierra Giganta

462120352.reviewBody: This trip to the mission was worth it even just for the magnificent road that winds its way through the Sierra Giganta; every turn is a surprise, a breath-taking view. And when you get to San Javier it\'s like stepping into a different time, small tidy white-washed houses with thatched roofs along cobbled streets and, at the bottom of the main street, the severe mission church with the majestic mountains as a backdrop. \nWhen we got there there were two lovely men at the entrance who gave us information on the mission and told us to walk through the orchard at the back of the church to the olive grove where there is an ancient olive tree that had been planted by the original missionaries. \nWe came back the following day to take more pictures of both the Mission and the Sierra Giganta\'s landscapes.

458747573.name: Mission San Javier
458747573.author: a TripAdvisor user
458747573.reviewBody: Beautiful gem of a mission, the second in the Baja California, located 36 km West or Loreto. Rugged mountains surround the Artesian spring-fed rivers which were channeled into canals to use for agricultural irrigation and drinking water. The mission and pueblo are in the high desert, but it is not a barren landscape. \nThe Jesuit mission is intact and built with black lava blocks and river rocks. The three altar screens are gilt and transported from the mainland and the European baroque icons are from Spain. Very beautiful and worth the trip whether or not you are religious or interested in missions.

454627224.name: Mission San Javier - be prepared before you come, but it is worth the drive off the beaten path!
454627224.author: a TripAdvisor user
454627224.reviewBody:
I have been reading about the Mission San Javier in anticipation of bringing 50 people on a road trip to visit the mission.   Four of the group have been living in the Baja for 25 years, and this was to be their first visit, so I read.  I became so confused, I quit reading!  Every review had the opposite information so I will give you my report from January 2017.

Leaving Hwy 1 near Loreto the road is fully paved.  Hardly a pothole to be found.  It is a beautiful drive - make sure your windows are clean!

Take care as you wind through the mountains - they are doing road construction on a curve and installing drainage.  The detour was a little confusing even with a construction worker directing us, so drive slowly and take the time to know which road they want you to drive on.  

We encountered three places where we had to drive through water.  We got out and looked to make sure it was not too deep - it was only a few inches.  We were in a small suv and it was no problem.  

Once we arrived the church was open and staffed by a gentleman that only spoke Spanish.  That was no problem for us, but it could be if you don't speak Spanish.  Both the Mission San Javier and Mission in Loreto claim to be the first in the chain of the California Missions.  It doesn't really matter - both are worth seeing!

The Mission San Javier is a very drab looking church - not a put down - it's just old and in its original condition.  It feels very "real" because it is.  You can feel the toil of the workers that cut and hauled the volcanic stone blocks from the surrounding hills.  Take some time to reflect while you are there.  Look out the church front doors to the orange tree lined boulevard and imagine you are in Sevilla, Spain, which has streets that look just like this one.  The seeds for the trees came from somewhere in Southern Spain and were brought by ship to the mission orchard.

To our disappointment we found out that the ancient Cave Paintings we came to hike to were covered up or wiped out by Hurricane Odile two years ago.  The next set of cave paintings is an hour away then an hour hike.  It was too close to dark to attempt that, so we settled on a short hike to see the amazingly twisted 300 year old olive tree behind the Mission and the irrigation system still being used after 300 years.

We did manage to exit the canyon at dusk.  I would not advise staying until dark.  Although encountering cows, a heard of goats, and fording streams is entertaining it isn't advised to be out in an isolated area at night - even with 49 of your best friends.  Enjoy!

To think 400 to 500 years ago they sailed from Spain around tierra del fuego then up to the baja bringing all the stained glass and paintings among other things is mind blowing .had a wonderful time ,a must see

444911539.name: Make the drive!

444119115.name: Amazing historical structure way up in the mountains
444119115.author: a TripAdvisor user
444119115.reviewBody: The San Javier Mission leaves one wondering - why and how?  How did the people back in the 1600\'s manage to build this cathedral and surrounding buildings?  And, why?  The building is huge - the surrounding grounds are very interesting - including a dam and irrigation system for local fields.  The Mission and area is no longer "new" - it shows signs of years of use and lack of upkeep.  The drive up through the mountains is very scenic and it is worth the time to walk around the Mission and area to see what once was.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

444066131.name: Beautiful historic and lively place
444066131.author: a TripAdvisor user
444066131.reviewBody: Not too far from Loreto distance wise, but some parts of the road were being repaired, so it\'s best to have a high vehicle to get to the Mission. The festivities of San Javier happen the first weekend in December, so the whole town was getting ready to host the pilgrimage that brings back hundreds of people. The church itself is quite bare, mainly due to the remote location, and part of the tour are the olive orchards and some amazing samples of irrigation technology developed over 300 years ago. We took a tour that was lead by someone with family in the town, so instead of having a lunch in a restaurant, our group had the opportunity to eat at one of the local ranches where tortillas were made by hand, and the lady was very open and hospitable and even let one of the girls in our group try herself. Not as easy as it looks. There\'s a lot of living history here, so you\'re better off reading some before you get up there. The drive up the mountains is beautiful. Definitely a must see.

The drive to the mountains is also well worth the time.  We gained a new appreciation for the hardiness of the Jesuits who settled this remote area.

441242330.name: Second Oldest Jesuit Mission in Baja California Sur
441242330.author: a TripAdvisor user
441242330.reviewBody:
The Jesuits started in Baja in Loreto with mission number one, Our Lady of Loreto. Then they moved up the mountain to the second site. They found plentiful fresh water here, built a reservoir and planted the olive trees they brought from Spain. We saw one that was probably original to the site. Twisted and enormous, it still bears fruit. 

The brothers built the mission out of indigenous rock, but had the ornamental stone pieces shipped from Spain, then carried them up the mountain foot path from Loreto to San Javier. Same with the gilt altar pieces and paintings. That was really faith in action!

The little San Javier  settlement still houses businesses and a school that serves all the  surrounding ranches as well as the little town. It is a beautiful drive up from Loreto, with lovely sea views and winding through local ranchos. There is road work, but persevere. It can seem harrowing, but the friendly road crews will guide you.

It is a worthwhile day trip; time well-spent if you are interested in history and/or religion.

437148200.name: Very nice museum
437148200.author: a TripAdvisor user
437148200.reviewBody: There was a funeral in the mission itself, so we spent our time in the museum next-door. There is a lot of information about the history of the missions in Baja California, and many beautiful artifacts from that period. Many, though not all, of the exhibits have a description in English as well as Spanish.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

435628918.name: Great for the history buff
435628918.author: a TripAdvisor user
435628918.reviewBody: Beautiful old mission church with great Spanish style architecture.  Attached museum has some very interesting pieces form the local area showing just how life was in the Baja.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

434964286.name: Beautiful mission blending in the mountains
434964286.author: a TripAdvisor user
434964286.reviewBody: Travel up the road about 25 miles from Loreto and make sure you stop and look back at the view of the town you left behind as you climb up to Mission San Xavier (Javier).  This is something you can do yourself or just hire a taxi that can take you there.  No need to hire expensive tour guides that mostly work for US companies.  Stay local, hire a taxi driver, many speak English and know the history just as well.  Ours made sure we tasted local fruits along the way, stopped each time we asked, gave us the history of even some of the people and horses we encountered.  The added bonus is that we didn\'t have to wait for others on tour to complete their picture taking, etc.  It was just us and the driver for 1/3 of the price.  Another added bonus (we live on a boat and were at anchor), he picked us up at the beach....  Great 1/2 day tour.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

434069244.name: Mission San Javier
434069244.author: a TripAdvisor user
434069244.reviewBody: A great side trip if you are staying in Loreto or at the nearby Villa Del Palmar Loreto resort. This is one of the oldest missions in the California\'s and remains relatively unchanged since its establishment. You can drive up or enjoy a tour offered by the resort or arrange in Loreto. The road up is a bit of a challenge, mostly paved, but rough in some spots and provides a magical transition into another era. /there is an annual festival that attracts thousands - probably best to avoid unless you like huge crowds. Good for families. Highly recommended.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

433052496.name: Mission Basilica
433052496.author: a TripAdvisor user
433052496.reviewBody: This church is the first of the California missions, established on October 25, 1697. The museum next door explains the history of Baja California in artifacts, illustrations and excellent postings. Visit here and your trip to Loreto will take on a deeper meaning and better understanding of this first capital of Baja.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

431000175.name: It\'s about the journey
431000175.author: a TripAdvisor user
431000175.reviewBody: The mission is pretty cool to see but the drive up and back was awesome. It\'s a really beautiful drive. Parts of the road are a little sketchy and a section had been washed away completely but still very doable. Work was being done, not sure how long it will take. Since we drove ourselves we appreciated the guide in the mission. His english wasn\'t great but good enough. He pointed out lots of stuff we would have missed. He works for tips. We were planning on eating in San Javier, there\'s a restaurant that the tours all go to next to the mission. Unfortunately when we walked in a group eating there told us the flies were so bad they were unable to eat their food. So with that warning we passed. That\'s a good reason to drive yourself. There isn\'t much else but the mission in San Javier so you\'d have much more flexibility.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

429876745.name: Mountain Drive to Charming Mission
429876745.author: a TripAdvisor user
429876745.reviewBody:
We booked this through our resort, and had an excellent guide...although the history lesson while seated in the church was a bit long! Those benches are hard!
The road can be a bit scary...especially after rain, but take it easy...our guide seemed to have no issues (and I was up front and saw the road!).
It's a small village, but there are a couple of places to eat, and some small cooperatives where there are handicrafts...note I said small. Be sure to ask the guide how much time you have in the village, as we thought we could wander, and had about 5 minutes after the lunch!
The mission is beautifully maintained, and worth walking around the exterior, as well as the interior. There are loose stones around the church, so good shoes might make sense. Bring a camera too...the scenery is beautiful, and the fruit trees will either be in bloom or have fruit!
It's worth understanding the history, as it is quite remote and in the mountains...imagine building that under those circumstances...no highways in those days to bring materials!

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

428948332.name: Oasis in the mountains.
428948332.author: a TripAdvisor user
428948332.reviewBody: We took a guided tour from our hotel. The drive took us into the mountains to a plateau at the top where the indigenous Indians lived hundreds of years ago.  They planted fruit trees, palm trees, olive trees, vines.  A beautiful location.  Streams and ponds are full all year.  The Mission is extremely old but beautiful. From 1699.  Inside you will see a gold alter and many portraits of San Javier.  Lunch in a little outdoor restaurant next to the Mission.   Dates and olives for dessert. Loved everything about this day!

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

428947737.name: Gorgeous old mission
428947737.author: a TripAdvisor user
428947737.reviewBody: We drove ourselves to the mission on a very rough road that can be quite dangerous but if you are careful it\'s no problem.  Once you get to town you immediately see this lovely mission.  It is in great shape, with lovely icons and great structure. There are some small restaurants in town, nothing special but fun to eat there if hungry.  Not sure this is a trip for kids unless they are adventurous.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

428551076.name: Old
428551076.author: a TripAdvisor user
428551076.reviewBody: I was surprised to learn that this mission was built in 1697. I did not realize that there were any non native buildings that old.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

427675541.name: Recent visit
427675541.author: a TripAdvisor user
427675541.reviewBody: Had the chance to visit the Mission during an off season. The road to the mission is a disaster, as multiple areas have been washed out, and have yet to be repaired by the country. Only take a shuttle to avoid damaging a rental car. The town is one street of nothing interesting. The only restaurant serves below average food. The mission is old, dirty, and almost appears abandoned. To see some pieces of art which are hundreds of years old in such poor conditions is heart wrenching. It was interesting to see the grounds of the mission, with the old olive trees and water irrigation system, but it was disappointing to see the Mission in such condition.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

427104235.name: Very pretty drive.
427104235.author: a TripAdvisor user
427104235.reviewBody: A nice drive up the mountain with a few parts of the road under construction. The mission is very quaint and historical and a must see. Don\'t forget to walk behind the mission to see the very old olive grove with the amazing trees. Have lunch in the little restaurant that sits it front of the mission. Look for the lime tree. The owner will serve you the limes and they are sweet tasting and delicious.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

420974606.name: Worth the drive.
420974606.author: a TripAdvisor user
420974606.reviewBody: Head up to the mountains where it is cooler and greener. Check out the mission and the 1000 year old olive tree. Eat lunch at one of the small family run restaurants where the owner  picks  the limes off the trees to put in your cervezas! Also a good place to hide from the torrential rain that hit while we were there.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

410089736.name: History in the hills
410089736.author: a TripAdvisor user
410089736.reviewBody: When most people think about Mexico, they see shots of tequila and getting sunburned on the beach.  Mexico is steeped in Spanish history much like the west and southwest United States.  As such, there is a chain of missions along the mountains and allies of Baja California.  San Javier is one of the jewels in this chain.  It\'s about a 15 minute drive from the main road.  It\'s a scenic route.  The mission is beautiful, and in great condition.  The cemetery hosts a number of graves dating back centuries.  Check the schedule before you go.  They have a fair and market on certain days.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

409718700.name: An Enjoyable Sunday Drive
409718700.author: a TripAdvisor user
409718700.reviewBody: We drive to this Mission each time we go to Loreto...it is a beautiful drive up the windy, coastal mountains.  Take the drive, along with plenty of water...definitely worthwhile!

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

408792001.name: Misi\u00f3n de San Javier /San Javier Mission
408792001.author: a TripAdvisor user
408792001.reviewBody: The paved highway to get there is a huge bonus to this historic attraction. In less than an hour you can travel back in time and really fall in awe by the stamina the Jesuits had to get here/ A s\u00f3lo una hora de Loreto por una carretera pavimentada puedes imaginarte los esfuerzos que los Jesuitas tuvieron que hace para hacerse caminos entre esta sierra. \n

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

407126366.name: Great place
407126366.author: a TripAdvisor user
407126366.reviewBody: For sure having to visit, 40 minute drive threw the mountains, the have a couple of nice restaurants. Worth having a look at.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

404285618.name: Amazing
404285618.author: a TripAdvisor user
404285618.reviewBody: This is a must see when visiting the area. Such an amazing story. Drive takes 45 min from the main road.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

400405067.name: Magic place!
400405067.author: a TripAdvisor user
400405067.reviewBody: We were driving for 4 hours from La Paz to Loreto me everybody was kind of skeptical when I suggested another hour driving up the mountain to see this mission...but surprise surprise I convinced them and all enjoyed very much the scenarios offered by the mission surrounded by mountains where time seems to have stopped a long time ago. We met Jorge how was our guide and offered a lot of information about the mission, the town and history. There are no real guides in this place, you basically walk around asking if someone is willing to take you for a walk, at the and you give him a tip. This place offers great photography opportunities especially on sunrise and sunset hours for which I\'m considering to go back to stay overnight. Well worth the effort to get up there.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

397092364.name: Easy trip from Loreto
397092364.author: a TripAdvisor user
397092364.reviewBody: I initially thought the road to Mision San Javier was unpaved. When I visited it on my motorcycle I was disappointed to find out it was paved :-). The mision is well maintained and in pristine condition. It is pretty interesting to see a small cemetery right next to the mission. The mission is a perfect subject for great photography.\n\nSlow down, sit and watch the slow pace of the village surrounding it. Peaceful.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

396944663.name: Worth the stop for sure!
396944663.author: a TripAdvisor user
396944663.reviewBody: This is a Jesuit church built in the 1700\'s.  An amazing work, and very well preserved.  Never crowded, a historic landmark for sure.  You leave the main highway 1 at San Ignacio and just head into town.  You cannot miss the plaza and church.  Good eats near there as well.  This mission photos great!  If you are driving by San Ignacio, stop here for sure!!!

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

388814373.name: Beautiful Mission
388814373.author: a TripAdvisor user
388814373.reviewBody: This is the 2nd mission built and is very beautiful but in somewhat fragile condition. The drive up from Loreto is a little rough but a rental car can make it with no trouble. If you know a little spanish, you can get a great tour from the caretaker.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

385300594.name: Visit to the Mission
385300594.author: a TripAdvisor user
385300594.reviewBody: Went to the mission while we were there. The city of Loreto is restoring the mission. It is open daily.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

381590575.name: Beautiful Historic Spot
381590575.author: a TripAdvisor user
381590575.reviewBody: We stopped in for a look while we were in Loreto. The Mission was built in the 1600s and is very well preserved. There were people there praying so we didn\'t stay long, but it was amazing to see.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

379781633.name: Loretto Mountains
379781633.author: a TripAdvisor user
379781633.reviewBody: We rented a car for the week and we drove up to the mission one day. The road is not to bad (2-lane, no shoulders) and at some point the road was being repaired (big-time) for a flash flood maybe happened during the winter. It is off-season, so no traffic what-so-ever. Passed two cars the entire 25 miles. Worth a look since it is in the mountains and near a spring. Town is very small and there are a few places for snacks. We didn\'t eat there. It is amazing it was built at the time and in this canyon. Loreto was the capital once probably because of this. place.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

376590536.name: Not the easiest to find, but well worth the trip
376590536.author: a TripAdvisor user
376590536.reviewBody: This mission is located up a steep and windy road. It is paved, but there is construction on places where the road was washed out due to rains. The road is also a bit hard to see from the main highway. We breezed by it the first time, circled back when we realized that we had gone too far, saw a tour van turn onto the road, and followed them. The mission is fairly isolated, yet very well maintained. Hard to believe that construction was started in 1699. We basically had the place to ourselves, and were so glad we made the trip.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

376436496.name: Worth the ride!
376436496.author: a TripAdvisor user
376436496.reviewBody: The Mission is outside Loreto on a windy, sometimes bumpy road for about 40 minutes but worth the ride! It is beautifully maintained and holds such interesting history. The grounds and surrounding neighborhood are quaint and friendly. You can visit on your own or there are guided tours, too. The vistas and views are incredible!

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

375612044.name: Mission San Javier
375612044.author: a TripAdvisor user
375612044.reviewBody: We had a rental car and drove up the mountain to the mission.  Along they way are some farms and we waited for a small herd of goats to cross.  The road was winding and narrow, but not scary.  The mission was beautiful and there was a man who gave us information and some history.  We had some lunch at Pablo\'s, but I would not rate it as fantastic.  The beer was  nice a cold though.  It is worth the drive up if you like to see cute little towns and old churches.  We had heard about the 400 year olive tree, so we wandered out behind the church and found it.  There is nothing marking it, but there was a table with a book to sign in.  We were staying at Villa del Palmar and there is no sign showing where to turn from that direction, so we had to back track.  There is a sign if you are driving from the town of Loreto.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

372693049.name: Built in 1699
372693049.author: a TripAdvisor user
372693049.reviewBody: The things the Jesuits did to get converts to Catholicism! This church is so remote, on the top of rugged, dry, desert mountains. I can\'t imagine hauling stones from the beach area by donkey, and walking high up into these desolate mountains to build a church to get the indigenous people to accept Catholicism! For this reason the church is amazing and probably worth the hour drive to get to it. There are less than 200 people living in the Puebla now so nothing else to do there except maybe grab a bite at one of the two food stands. I heard the burritos are very good but we didn\'t try them.\n\n

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

372208311.name: Peaceful beauty
372208311.author: a TripAdvisor user
372208311.reviewBody: The mission is so beautiful,both inside & out. A peaceful atmosphere and great artifacts,centuries old.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

372025865.name: True historic place
372025865.author: a TripAdvisor user
372025865.reviewBody: I found this drive very enjoyable. During the hour of winding desert canyon road I passed eight cars going the other way. This is out away from others. There are food options in San Javier. The church is a heritage piece yet it is a long drive to only see it.  I liked seeing the beauty of the mountains and terrain and had a wonderful day.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

369793527.name: Peaceful Mission and Small Village
369793527.author: a TripAdvisor user
369793527.reviewBody: After a drive up from Loreto through the arid hills one arrives at San Javier, a village in an area which had been inhabited by Guayacura indians.   The europeans arrived in the area in 1699 and the mission church was built in the mid-1700\'s.   The outside area has a pleasant garden including orange trees.   Behind the church are some irrigated gardens and plots of corn.  One can pay a fee to walk though an area with some rather ancient olive trees.   Note that there may be construction on the road up from Loreto, so you may be delayed for the roadwork.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

369632571.name: Interesting place -
369632571.author: a TripAdvisor user
369632571.reviewBody:
To think that the Jesuits traveled in this rugged, inhospitable country by foot all the
way up here is remarkable.  The trip itself is interesting if for no other reason that to
see some of the Baja back country.  The church itself is somewhat unremarkable but
it's construction and history is what makes the trip worthwhile.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

369400945.name: Mission
369400945.author: a TripAdvisor user
369400945.reviewBody: The mission is beautiful and it is a serene little town. Only go if you value missions and history. The hills around are beautiful and calming. The road can be a little scary to get there,  but not too bad. There are great views going up to San javier.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

368479615.name: Worth the drive.
368479615.author: a TripAdvisor user
368479615.reviewBody: If you enjoy history and are amazed by early explorers and feats of engineering and agriculture, make the drive. If you enjoy old churches and the awe of standing in the same place that great people stood hundreds of years ago, don\'t miss this.  \n\nWalk the farm and see what early settlers were able to accomplish. Then eat at the little restaurant with the Modelo sign out front. Pablo\'s I think. Have a beer. They are COLD!!!  Food is great. Salsa is hot!!

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

367051780.name: Must See Side Trip
367051780.author: a TripAdvisor user
367051780.reviewBody: Experience a Baja Side trip and see how the Franciscan Missionaries started the California Missionary Trail

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

366704990.name: An amazing place to visit. Very well worth the time.
366704990.author: a TripAdvisor user
366704990.reviewBody: The olive tree is worth the visit alone.  We assumed no services were available and took our own lunch to learn some of the best food on the Baja is there.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

366076486.name: Mountain high retreat
366076486.author: a TripAdvisor user
366076486.reviewBody: After an enchanting drive up the mountain from Loreto, we arrived at the tiny village home to Mission San Javier, a beautiful retreat from the world. In this serene setting, the church stands tall, a beacon to wander in and behind,  leaving present-day thoughts behind. The building itself is worth the trip, with its ornate carvings and beautiful interior, but the orange tree, rose garden and olive grove surrounding it make you feel you have entered another world. Along side thee church is a small cemetery that begs to be captured on whatever media you have. Standing back, your eyes are pulled to the bell tower that seems to reach clear to the heavens, leading to other-than-worldly thoughts. Remarkable architecture for the 1600s,built to endure - surely not to be duplicated in today\'s throw-away society.There is no guide to answer questions, but there is a caretaker who might be around and he has delightful stories.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

365877987.name: Tour by Mule
365877987.author: a TripAdvisor user
365877987.reviewBody:
We arrived by mule on 10APR and enjoyed a luncheon as a part of a festival. Several hundred attended and the entertainment was fun.

The mission has much history and interesting architecture for such an old structure in such a remote location.

It's a village worth visiting.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

365837239.name: The road up to the Mission is spectacular!
365837239.author: a TripAdvisor user
365837239.reviewBody: Mission San Javier is a tiny town about 45 minutes away from Loreto.  Make sure you go behind the mission and walk through the old olive groves planted by the Jesuit missionaries in the early 1700\'s.  A lovely day trip to do from Loreto.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

365776663.name: A beautiful church
365776663.author: a TripAdvisor user
365776663.reviewBody: In downtown Loreto the mission was one of the first in Baja California and is a very tranquil place. It is very welcoming and if you time your visit you may get an escorted tour. When we were there a church service was in progress but all the locals were very welcoming and comfortable with tourists. Worth a visit

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

365532306.name: Stunning old Mission
365532306.author: a TripAdvisor user
365532306.reviewBody: Nice half day trip up the mountain to visit the Mission and enjoy lunch in the town. Currently road is fully paved except for small section that was washed out and under repair.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

364196965.name: Good place to visit
364196965.author: a TripAdvisor user
364196965.reviewBody: If you are in Loreto Baja California, its a must to visit the little town of San Javier. The mission has been there for since lated 1600\'s. a ggod place to eat too is la Palata just outside the mission.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

362555482.name: Fascinating step back in history
362555482.author: a TripAdvisor user
362555482.reviewBody: This mission, built by the Jesuits @1700, is amazing because of the incredible efforts that must have gone into building it such a long time ago in such inhospitable territory. I recommend taking a tour with Mario from Wild Loreto tours, as he is an expert on the region\'s history, and full of interesting stories.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

361278161.name: A beautiful Mission, year 1699! worth the drive from Loreto
361278161.author: a TripAdvisor user
361278161.reviewBody: Rented a car and drove up the mountain from Loreto to visit the Mission, the road is mostly paved, with some active construction working on gravel parts. The arroyos cross the road which means there may be some water in road at lowest part.  No problemo.  Our drive up took less than 40 minutes, and was a beautiful drive and destination. Take the time to walk in the privately owned olive trees  as well as around the entire Mission. It is a beautiful destination.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

361030602.name: Lovely small village at the end of dramatic drive
361030602.author: a TripAdvisor user
361030602.reviewBody: We rented a car in order to manage our time versus going on a tour. I realize we traded off information that could have been provided by a local guide since there is very little written at the Mission itself, there were no guides at the site, and the proprietor offers only the basic dates. However, we did look up information on the internet prior to going. The Mission is well worth seeing for its historical value and the pristine setting.  It requires less than 30 minutes to visit.  The village is very small with three cafes and one storefront that sells tourist items.  It also requires about 30 minutes to visit. The approximately 45 minute drive is very dramatic with lots of twists and turns into the mountains, several spots that were being repaired from rock fall and several that were covered by shallow water. It is NOT on the Pacific side so don\'t expect to get that view, although there are lovely views of the Sea of Cortez.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

360520924.name: A nice drive to a historical Mision
360520924.author: a TripAdvisor user
360520924.reviewBody: A beautiful drive to a wonderful Mision.  The second oldest in Baja California.  The Sacristan, the caretaker, is very friendly and knowleable.  I am told that mass is officiated every Thursday by the priest in Loreto.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

359182193.name: Worth the drive
359182193.author: a TripAdvisor user
359182193.reviewBody: Will go back for another visit. The kind of place where you see a lot but don\'t see everything in a single visit. Pretty well maintained for a 1697 building.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

358237958.name: Spectacular views around this mission
358237958.author: a TripAdvisor user
358237958.reviewBody: When you reach this place the best thing you can do is to hire a local guide that will tell you some stories about the mission and about the local community living around the old church. Great trip if you\'re staying in Loreto, definitely worth it

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

358182904.name: Lovely drive
358182904.author: a TripAdvisor user
358182904.reviewBody:
We took a trip up to San Javier from Loreto in our own car. The road is much improved from years ago. The drive is lovely with several lush areas amidst the arid landscape where a river ran through. There are a couple of ranches on the way but we did not know if you could stop and visit. The cave paintings are now buried under rubble following the aftermath of a hurricane. 

The mission is lovely. A gentleman inside who may have been a tour guide, was able to provide some history and information of interest but in limited English. Be prepared to offer him a tip and also a donation to the mission. 

There was not much to do in the town but we relaxed at a vendor and had a pop. I also saw at least one restaurant and a couple of souvenir if places. We went on a Sunday and waited for mass to finish. We could have gone the day before but there was a cruise ship visiting Loreto and so we thought it might be quite busy.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

357194437.name: Neat drive to a 17th Century Mission - 1699!
357194437.author: a TripAdvisor user
357194437.reviewBody:
A drive to a Mission on the Pacific side of Baha.  We enjoyed the drive as much as the Mission, but both are impressive.

I couldn't help but wonder how the early settlers navigated the mountains to build this church.  Amazing history!

The Mission is in a small village with a few small "restaurants" where you can get a bite and a cold drink.  If you are offered local "cookies" filled with fruit - buy, eat, and enjoy!  They are great!

We had no idea the distance from Loreto to the Mission, so we "negotiated" hard with the taxi driver for the trip.  Once we experienced the distance - he got a nice tip - and it was well earned!

Roads are repaired from the last hurricanes and very passable.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

357186042.name: A great example of landscape architecture, beautifully conserved
357186042.author: a TripAdvisor user
357186042.reviewBody: About one hour drive from Loreto, this mission is very well preserved. The little village is lovely and the people there very friendly. Do not forget to visit the olive tree in the backyard, it is supposed to be 400 year old.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

355834235.name: Lovely historic mission worth the trip up
355834235.author: a TripAdvisor user
355834235.reviewBody: 34 km up a mountain paved road, mostly in good shape to reach San Javier Mision, just south & West of Loreto Baja California Mexico.  Spectacular setting for this quiet, well kept village which sees a lot of visitors, but seems to have maintained its roots.

355725412.name: Alive with people
355725412.author: a TripAdvisor user

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

355360365.name: Well worth the drive
355360365.author: a TripAdvisor user
355360365.reviewBody: Beautiful town with a magnificent Mission hidden in the la Giganta Sierra, the drive is around 45 mins from Loreto, small town surrender by an Oasis, the locals are extremely friendly, don\'t forget to try the goat cheeses and mango marmalade

355329493.name: Mission San Javier
355329493.author: a TripAdvisor user
355329493.reviewBody: Must see very cool, the museum attached is nice there is a small fee, (100 pesos) to walk through. It is in the square so easy to find

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

354665681.name: This mission is a must see.
354665681.author: a TripAdvisor user
354665681.reviewBody: We took our friends up this time. They loved it as do we. Once you pass through the mission you must wander back to the old massive olive trees and then walk the main street and shop or have a bite to eat. Very peacefull. And interesting fact is that the property behind the mission has been purchased and they are installing a gate. It is located after passing the big olive trees and before the cisterns. We donated some pesos for the cause and walked in. They will be creating a place where people can barbeque and hang out. They are using the donations for the project.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

354386828.name: Visiting the San Javier Mission is a must!
354386828.author: a TripAdvisor user
354386828.reviewBody: We rented a car and drove ourselves to the Mission.  However, while we were there, a van of visitors arrived.  The road is a curvy mountainous road--but the Mission is worth the car ride to see it!  We were met by a gentleman at the door who gave us a wonderful tour of the mission.  It is amazing and should be added to your list of things to do while in Loreto!

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

354325374.name: Nice place, out of the way
354325374.author: a TripAdvisor user
354325374.reviewBody: Not much to add to all the other reviews on the Mission, Pretty cool place to see, but not overly exciting or amazing. It\'s a bit of a drive to get to it, but a very interesting one through the desert and canyons.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

354215252.name: If you only do one thing go there
354215252.author: a TripAdvisor user
354215252.reviewBody: This is a gorgeous little village with one of the most beautiful missions I have ever seen. It is well worth the drive. We went with a great taxi driver named Oscar. He took us to his family\'s ranch where his mother-in-law made us home-made chicken fajitas. He told us about the history of San Javier and the mission. It was originally built in 1699. It is in the mountains with gorgeous trees, including a sprawling olive tree on the grounds. It is a very peaceful place.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

353949516.name: A trip worth making up the mountain
353949516.author: a TripAdvisor user
353949516.reviewBody:
Saturday tour:
San Javier:
The road beautifully paved, except for a maybe 1/4 mile section washed out in heavy rains. 

The town beautiful, clean, a few shops, restaurants and a few cottages to overnight if one wanted.

The mission open, if one knows the language a volunteer explains much of the history and things to see. The mission is also beautifully maintained.

The restaurant, La Palapa de San Javier, excellent service, excellent food, reasonable pricing, 2 meals and drinks for 4 $250.

A trip worth making. 

2 events up coming, one 11 May and a bigger one 1-3 Dec.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

353942733.name: Great road trip!
353942733.author: a TripAdvisor user
353942733.reviewBody: The drive to the mission is beautiful. You get to see mountains and the desert and occasionally you are surprised by lush vegetation where there are sources of water. You do need to watch out for goats, cows  and road runners crossing the road. Approx 1/4 k of the road is washed away, however it is ok to drive, The old Mission is spectacular in terms of age and history. It must have been challenging to build.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

353431598.name: Amazing Mission in the mountains
353431598.author: a TripAdvisor user
353431598.reviewBody: The drive to San Javier is beautiful but not well marked.  The Mission is amazing and it is hard to imagine the amount of work that went into building it.  An old olive tree, irrigation system and rock paved roads add to the interest and enjoyment of the Mission.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

353428928.name: Long winding road
353428928.author: a TripAdvisor user

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

352901802.name: Peaceful Spot
352901802.author: a TripAdvisor user
352901802.reviewBody: Although it is a drive to get there, the Mission is well worth it. It is located in a sort of bowl, with the mountains surrounding it. The tiny town is old Mexico, and the quiet and beautiful architecture of the Mission shine. We loved the history of the Jesuits, and our guide, Mario with Wild Loreto, was the best. He really brought the story alive. We had a simple but outstanding lunch in the small restaurant by the Mission. A must see.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

352738230.name: Great trip.
352738230.author: a TripAdvisor user
352738230.reviewBody: Outstanding experience and pretty mission \nWe bought candy from a vender and the people are so nice. Old olive trees and tons of orange tree which smelled great thru out the city. Nice drive up the mountains.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

352425607.name: Fascinating history and a fun drive up there!
352425607.author: a TripAdvisor user
352425607.reviewBody: The site of the first Mission in Baja California Sur with an interesting history, reputedly the first olive tree in BCS, a pretty little village and a beautiful winding 30km drive with spectacular views.  Go to the restaurant and ask for a super refreshing jugo de lima - limas are a cross between lemons and oranges.  You may even meet Guillermo bringing them in from his huerto.  Enjoy!

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

350606828.name: Beautiful and Centrally Located
350606828.author: a TripAdvisor user

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

350005186.name: Nice landscape on the way
350005186.author: a TripAdvisor user
350005186.reviewBody: My hotel booked a taxi for me to go there at $70. I would say it is very expensive for just a half day trip. However, Loreto is a very small town without any public transport. If I can\'t find another travellor to share, I have to pay all the cost. Honestly speaking, the mission looks just a normal little church. But the drive all the way was really pleasant. The mountains have interesting rock formations. There are oasis inside those dry lands. It is worthy of the money to go there. As the driver can\'t speak English, I had to read some information of the history online.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

349837742.author: a TripAdvisor user

349002481.name: Worth Seeing

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

348345349.name: Amazing Mountain Range, Beautiful Oasis, Stunning Architecture
348345349.author: a TripAdvisor user
348345349.reviewBody: The drive is so much better now that they have the road almost complete.  The \'Gigantica Mountain Range and the Green Oasis\' makes the trip very enjoyable.  The old Catherdral in Juarez is an amazing stone structure and the fruit filled orange trees are so perfect they almost don\'t seem real.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

348306088.name: Remarkable mission
348306088.author: a TripAdvisor user
348306088.reviewBody: This was founded in 1699 by the Jesuits, and took over 30 years to build. It\'s one of the first buildings in the Californias to have glass windows. Given the harshness of the climate, and the inaccessibility of the terrain, I think this is a remarkable place.\n\nThe drive from Loreto is a hair-raising 40 minute ride through sharp bends, rock falls, water splashes and cactus canyons. It\'s worth going to the mission for the drive alone!

348298969.author: a TripAdvisor user
348298969.reviewBody: I loved the woodwork that was part of the mission, and its little side garden. It is not truly inspiring, but it is lovely to see and realize its historical significance.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

346411039.name: Magical Mountain Mission
346411039.author: a TripAdvisor user
346411039.reviewBody: Mission San Javier is a must see while visiting Loreto.  Before you ever even arrive, you enjoy the absolutely stunning and breathtaking scenery of the La Giganta Mountains.  The mission itself is well preserved. The chapel inside is truly unique as the main alter features San Javier, Mary, Joseph.  Jesus has a spot on the left of th e misison.  The is lunch restaurant outside.  Don\'t forget ot stroll the grounds.  Look for the amazing 300 year old olive tree.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

346409089.name: Outstanding Architecture
346409089.author: a TripAdvisor user
346409089.reviewBody: Mission San Javier is an outstanding original example of early 1700 spanish architecture.   It was the first mission to have glass windows.  The drive takes about an hour and there is only a very small stretch where the road is dirt and gravel.  There are animals and streams to see on the way along with a small chapel about half way.   Be sure to go out behind the church and walk through the old olive orchards.   There are original trenches still there and the community is still farming.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

346358349.name: A bit of old Mexico
346358349.author: a TripAdvisor user
346358349.reviewBody: It\'s not a grandiose Gothic cathedral in the European style, but it is a living reminder of a cornerstone of Mexican culture, and of early California history.  It still functions as a church, and tourists are welcome to worship at their services.\nThe neighboring museum offers an overview of early colonial history in the California territories, along with some typical artifacts. Almost every display includes a lengthy explanation in English, so visitors don\'t need to know Spanish. However,some of the history presented glosses over the more brutal aspects of the Spanish conquest and colonization; the native population of Baja California declined from 50,000 to less than 5,000 during that period. Nevertheless, the museum provides some useful insights into frontier life and history.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

345873190.name: Beautiful and peaceful
345873190.author: a TripAdvisor user
345873190.reviewBody: Loved the drive!  The mountain are gorgeous and very unexpected.  The mission was beautiful and we visited during a very peaceful morning.  Would love to hike the area next time.

335705440.name: Historic Place in a Hidden Valley
335705440.author: a TripAdvisor user
335705440.reviewBody: We truly enjoyed the ride to and from the mission. The views of Sierra de la Giganta, the winding roads, and the stunning views of the Sea of Cortez on the return trip are already worth the time and effort. The trip takes about one hour each way from Loreto. The mission church makes an impression with its gilded altar, impressive stonework and glass windows (the first in this part of the world). The surrounding buildings, walls and small cemetery are also worth exploration.There is no one to give information about the mission, but if you need something to eat, there is a small restaurant across from the church. I gave this attraction 5 stars for the object itself (it was built at the end of the 17th century it this remote location!) and for the trip there which has really beautiful views.

313088609.name: Picturesque Old Town and Mission Surrounded by Rock Cliffs
313088609.author: a TripAdvisor user
313088609.reviewBody:
This small remote town is unspoiled and looks like a scene from "The Treasure of Sierra Madre."  The mission is well preserved and worth the time to explore it as well as the grounds that run for some distance through the old mission orchard down the canyon.
There are some small stores there that offer local wines, curios and other items.
There is almost always at least one restaurant open that offers regional cuisine.
Once a year (I think it is in the fall) the town is filled with people from all around the state who come for the Fiesta de San Xavier.  The mission is either the second or the third mission built in the chain that ran northward through what is now California. 
The access is by (mostly) paved road.  There have been spots that were washed out in recent hurricanes but should all easily be traveled by car.  
You might travel a mile or two beyond the town (take the road to the left of the mission) to visit the pictographs from the earliest indigenous inhabitants of the area.  That road may or may not be easilly driven by low clearance vehicles.  Inquire in town to be sure it is passable.
This is an off-the-beat town that is a window to old (and VERY old-time) Baja.

285901156.name: Worthwhile 1/2-day trip to the 18th Century!
285901156.author: a TripAdvisor user
285901156.reviewBody:
Rented a standard manual transmission beater car in Loreto (nickname: El Burro Rojo) to explore the area on a weeklong trip in December 2014. On our last day, we decided to take El Burro on a trip up into the mountains to see San Javier. Our innkeepers in Loreto said the road -- literally, "The Road to San Javier" -- was "probably passable" without a 4WD, but due to some recent rains, they told us to stop before any water crossing and send someone out ahead to wade through first to check the depth. Good advice! 

At our first crossing, we saw a loaded tour van stop on the other side of the stream, and roughly 15 people got out to walk across. The unloaded van made it, so we felt confident that El Burro Rojo could make it, too. See photos. Yes, we are those people who should know better.

There were 3 water crossings one-way, and all were OK (well, the first one was a bit hairy). The twisty-turny mountain drive was actually very, very fun. Paved most of the way, and dirt sections were in good condition (no big ruts, potholes, etc.) Once we arrived at San Javier, the scene was simply mesmerizing -- a slice of 18th-century California preserved in time and space in a breathtaking mountain oasis setting. 

We spent about an hour walking through the little town and exploring the mission & grounds. 200 people reportedly call San Javier home, but when we were there in late December it felt deserted. There is a small residential neighborhood on the opposite side of town from the Mission, with an elementary school, etc. The vibe was other-wordly, eerie, and strangely beautiful. It's challenging to imagine what life must have been like 200 years ago for the local folks and missionaries in this desolate, unforgiving, and glorious place. If you are a photographer, you will love it.

It\'s worth walking all the way around the mission and checking out the iguanas all over the walls. 260804084.name: Drive was doable in a VW Jetta! Quaint town & gorgeous drive!
260804084.author: a TripAdvisor user
260804084.reviewBody:
St Javier

St Javier is an absolute must see if you are in the area. Not only is the drive towards the quaint town remarkable, but the mission & town are certainly worthwhile. We left Loreto at 2:30, arrived at 3:30 and were the only tourists there during our visit (from 3:30-5). 

- take your time to notice the mountains & creeks as you drive (the road is rather windy, so you'll have to  slow down anyhow)

- the road does have a few areas where you must cross over a creek and one 300 meter stretch that is unpaved. When we drove on March 17 only two of the creeks were noteworthy. The road is designed for this to happen, and our car was perfectly fine (a VW Jetta). The first crossing was the deepest, at 6inches or so, and the water was very slow moving.  TIP: You should drive slowly through the water to ensure that you don't pull water into your engine (although this is unlikely). TIP: check locally to see if there has been recent rain, which would change conditions of the road. 

- the mission doesn't charge an entrance fee, but there is an area for donations. If you'd like to buy a candle to light you can buy one at the tourist shop on the Main Street for 15pesos

- the washroom is in the restaurant, soft drinks were inexpensive, should you want to support the local business (we didn't eat there)
