260108762.name: A day trip to San Javier Mission in Loreto worth the drive!
260108762.author: a TripAdvisor user
260108762.reviewBody:
My husband and I decided we needed a break from relaxing at the beach during our recent visit to Loreto Bay so we decided to venture to the mission in the small, remote mountain village of San Javier.  We had a compact rental car with not the best tires, but the road to the mission is paved although one needs to exercise caution ensuring you have adequate fuel before the trip (no Pemex in historical San Javier) and watch out for stray rocks and boulders on the road.  It is a windy curvy road with some wash-outs but nothing our little compact car couldn't handle, although you definitely want to depart from Loreto or Loreto Bay no later than 2 p.m. so you are returning before the sun sets between 6 p.m. and 6:30 p.m. as the road in the dark would prove to be risky, even for the adventurous!   The road to the Mision de San Fancisco Javier is a left just north of Nopolo and Loreto Bay, just past the Loreto airport or a right hand turn, just south of the town of Loreto before the airport.  There is some type of conservation sign that mentions San Javier but not a specific sign that indicates the mission name.  You will know you are on the correct road if you see a restaurant and grill on the right hand side of the road shortly after exiting off of highway one.  
The scenery is beautiful as you wind through the Sierra Gigantica range and I think it took us less than an hour to arrive to the mission (39.9 kms), making a stop enroute for a photo opportunity half way there on the right hand side of the road is another small historic chapel (unnamed)  across from a little oasis called Rancho Las Parras.  You can apparently buy green olives at this ranch and there is a little cemetary beyond the small chapel but we didn't find it.  
Enroute you will pass another ranch called Rancho Viejo where the mission was originally founded in 1699 and then moved to it's current site by Jesuit Fransisco Maria Picollo in 1720.  We were amazed at the detail in the architecture or the mission and of course it's location with the current day paved road and building amenities.  When we arrived we were greeted by the local perros (dogs) and a guide who asked for some information from us which he recorded in a visitors book.  We asked if we could take pictures inside which was permitted without the use of a flash.  The small town had a cobblestone road to the mission and looked very clean with some taquerias and apparently the original irrigation systems from centuries ago providing water to this day.  An orange tree right in front of the mission was in full bloom and the town also was graced with many olive trees.
We returned on the same road we came up on as we didn't know where the other road leading south west out of town would lead us and didn't want to risk as to what condition that road would be in but apparently it does go back past a few rural ranchos and eventually leads back to the paved San Isadro highway.

259436054.name: Great trek into the lush mountains of Loreto to see this gem of a Mission!
259436054.author: a TripAdvisor user
259436054.reviewBody:
I highly recommend hiring a car or a tour company to go see this gem of a Mission. The mission itself is nestled into a highland valley oasis, and acts as a beautiful backdrop to the small village that is San Javier.

Surprisingly, the road to San Javier is almost all paved, except a few dirt/rocky patches where the paved road has been washed away by hurricane flooding. You will have to drive through water in about 8-10 places during the wet season, but these passes are paved, and not too deep-- so just take it slow.

The mission itself is well preserved and taken care of. The surrounding scenery is something of a movie set, which is to say you won't believe you arrived in such a beautiful place.

The entire trip takes about 2.5 hours; more if you opt to have lunch in the village. Alternatively, you might consider packing a picnic lunch. You won't be disappointed.

255584259.name: Don\'t Miss San Javier!!

247808246.name: A Great Jaunt for the Day
247808246.author: a TripAdvisor user
247808246.reviewBody: Located 34 kilometres from the highway the Mission definitely is a worthwhile visit. My wife and I took a car through a number of water courses (10 in all) on the way. The water was approximately 15 cm or 6 inches deep in two locations. I wouldn\'t take a car to the mission after a rainfall, but we had little difficulty otherwise. The crossings are all concrete and you can see the road through the water in most cases. One section of the road has been affected by a landslide so it\'s about a 150 metre section of dirt but it is graded somewhat. Careful just above this section as the road is undermined a little on the cliff side. We enjoyed the mission. We learned a little from a guided group about the structure - and likely a guide would be more helpful - but we still spent a solid hour and a half here. The faces in the gold-leafed altar apparently are the faces of the artists. We also walked behind the church to the 200-year old twisted and thick olive tree and then ventured further along a concrete viaduct through the olive and fruit tree orchard. Some of the orchard trees were knocked down by Hurricane Odile. There is a small restaurant and a gift store (very basic items) in close proximity to the Mission. The only washroom we found is in the restaurant. It was a fun day!

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

246904368.name: Must See!
246904368.author: a TripAdvisor user
246904368.reviewBody:
We recommend taking a taxi (van) to the Mission; our driver, Oscar, was knowledgeable and provided opportunities to stop on the drive up the winding mountainside road.  As an experienced local, he provided side excursions that we would never have experienced on our own, like stopping to see a relative who raises goats and makes cheese in their rustic abode. 

After touring the mission church, don't overlook a short walk out back to see the very old (300 yrs, I believe) olive tree.  The tree still bears olives. 

Meals are available (and inexpensive) at a family-run restaurant at the Mission; but even if you choose to forego the meal, do stop for an ice-cold beverage.  The mission villiage is self-sustaining and somewhat dependent upon the visitors the come to the attraction.

Our trip was directly following the 2 hurricanes that had hit Baja and the hillsides were very green; but many of the stream-crossings were still being repaired from the flooding also.

240461578.name: Lovely Drive out to Mission San Javier
240461578.author: a TripAdvisor user
240461578.reviewBody: We had a lovely ride out to the beautiful little Mission San Javier.  Be sure and 1) Read about the mission history before going so you can appreciate it more.  There is not a lot to see once you arrive and understanding the background will enrich your experience.  2) Check the weather forecast and prepare to forge multiple small streams flowing over the road.  In our case, we had to cross a total of 12 (!).  While most were not intimidating, there were two that were deeper and we feared water would soon be coming in thru the bottom of the door.  If rain is expected, you may want to plan another day as you surely don\'t want to be stuck at the mission and unable to return to Loreto!

239848367.name: Yes! Yes! Yes!
239848367.author: a TripAdvisor user
239848367.reviewBody: We rented a car for the two weeks that we stayed in Loreto and I have to say that the 15 mile trip out to Mission San Javier was something of an adventure.  We crossed maybe a dozen small arroyos on the way with water flowing across the road.  Nothing to be worried about although I did take it very slowly through a couple of them.  And then there was the mile of the road that was under construction where it was just a bit difficult to figure out where to go.  But hey, it was all fun!\n\nAnd definitely worth it.  The Mission is a fascinating place and looks as it might have looked when it was first constructed.  We crawled around in a couple of rooms and areas that we probably weren\'t  supposed to enter but it gave us a good feel for what life must have been like in the mission during Colonial times.  Also gives you a much better understanding of how the Spanish were able to "settle" the country using isolated outposts scattered across the Mexican countryside.  But be forewarned - Mission San Javier is not a Cathedral with elaborate frescoes and statuary but it is definitely the real deal.

208773686.name: Well worth the drive
208773686.author: a TripAdvisor user
208773686.reviewBody:
I consider the road out to San Javier a good time.  Though its windy and has many detours that's Baja!  
I would not recommend the road to first time Baja drivers but if you are comfortable driving Baja roads then this is not much different.  Lots of road construction in May 2014.  
The road often narrows to 1 lane with drop-offs on either side.  

The town of San Javier is very small but very clean.  We did not spend time in the town.  
The mission is in great shape and there is a local that will show you around and talk with you a bit about the mission.  He was not pushy nor did he ask for money.  But I'm sure a few bucks was much appreciated.  
Its a must see, though at upwards of $75 (asking at some places in Loreto) would probably change my plans and skip it.  That's just really pricey for a 45min drive...

If you\'re flying into Loreto, I\'d recommend the side trip. If you\'re roadtripping Baja, I\'d suggest a stop at San Ignacio for a more accessible and very similar Mission experience in place.

205472388.name: Roll Back The Clock 300 Years!
205472388.author: a TripAdvisor user
205472388.reviewBody:
Well worth the drive from Loreto.  We rented a car from Alamo, and drove up the canyon. The carved stonework is stunning! I just oggled at the view of the mission, its white domes set against the stark mountainside. Be sure and tip the guide who hangs out to greet visitors and tells them the stories. Our guy was about the zillionth generation resident of the community of @ 200 people who live around the mission. 

On and around December 3 there is a huge celebration of the patron saint at the mission with hundreds--if not thousands--of people from all over congregating there.  Many people make the SEVEN HOUR walk from Loreto! 

There is a visitor center with local crafts for sale a short walk away. Cold drinks are available at the corner store--since they got wired electricity [replacing the old generator] sometime in the early 2000s.

After viewing the mission, walk down the path and see the 300 year old olive tree!  Continue past the tree--along the aqueduct--and visit Memo, who owns the land beyond the mission.  He's featured in "The Califonios" by Leland Foerster.  He has over 1,000 trees on his land.  A real "salt of the earth" person. He looks like he just stepped out from the old mission days!

If you go in the spring--or after a rain--be sure and stop at one or more of the washes that cross the road on the way up the canyon--if they have water.  Birding and wildlife sighting is excellent! At the mission, see if you can spot the house wrens that have made a home behind an impossibly small crack in the stones which face the front of the mission--@ 20 feet up, left of center! There are also canyon wrens in the area with their haunting descending trill.

205405889.name: Awesome.  Just don\'t eat in town there unless you want a good laugh.
205405889.author: a TripAdvisor user
205405889.reviewBody:
It was a great trip up through the mountains and then you see this oasis in the creek bed as you approach the town.  Very cool.  Lots of history, well preserved etc. etc... just like all the other reviews.

We tried to eat across the street at this little hut and we were the only ones there.  What I thought was going to be on of the most authentic mexican meals of the trip slowly turned into one of the weirdest lunches I have ever had.  

We ordered the super burros, which were supposed to be carne asada, cheese, rice etc.. and we asked for chips, salsa and guacamole, and five cokes.  

The lady went in the back for about 10 minutes and came out with pace picante sauce mixed with guacamole, spicy nacho doritos, and coca colas in plastic bottles.  Not what we were expecting as an authentic BCS meal.  

About 30 minutes had passed and we still didn't have the burritos.  My brother in law walked up to ask her if everything was okay and said he noticed 5 or 6 "Doritos, spicy nacho" bags on the floor of the "kitchen."  She said it takes a while for the range to heat up.  Oh well, we were in mexico no big deal.  

Then came the burritos.  homemade tortilla (YUM) which housed ground beef (what?), ketchup (what?), MUSTARD and MAYONNAISE (WHAAAAT?????).  I think was happened was they saw five gringos and made us american hamburger burritos thinking we would love them.  

It was insane but a super funny story to tell people.

The mission is awesome and its a nice trip up to it from Loreto.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

194990717.name: Great Day Trip
194990717.author: a TripAdvisor user
194990717.reviewBody: Great day trip.  Very interesting. Wild Loreto tour guides were excellent.  Tour Bus was new and comfortable.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

194684799.name: Peaceful and tranquil!
194684799.author: a TripAdvisor user
194684799.reviewBody: We took a trip up the mountain to this mission, about an hour away from the Villa Del Palmar. It is such a peaceful drive, although the roads are interesting in some places due to flooding but plenty of room left to drive on. The scenery is gorgeous. We arrived at the mission in a very quiet and sleepy town but everyone was very nice. The mission is a very old but simple church. We had to ask ourselves..."What is a mission doing on a mountainside in the middle of basically nowhere?" We found out the answer but you will have to go to discover it yourself. We explored the surrounding grounds and olive trees and other greenery. The most exciting thing was that they were preparing for a wedding. We have never seen so many fresh flowers in one place. We were even invited to the wedding! Stop by the caves on the way back down the mountain.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

193120618.name: Out of the Way in an Interesting Way
193120618.author: a TripAdvisor user
193120618.reviewBody: The mission itself is not all that spectacular. It\'s a simple old--very old--stone and wood church.  The particularly interesting part is that it\'s a couple of hour drive through beautiful austere mountains to a spot you that makes no sense for there to be a simple, very old church.  That in and of itself is inspiring.  \n\nWe ate lunch at a small family restaurant called, I think, Palapa San Javier. It\'s the first place on the left as you walk away from the mission.  Very nice folks; excellent food. A surprising find in what counts as the real middle of nowhere.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

192811932.name: Exceptionally beautiful mission
192811932.author: a TripAdvisor user
192811932.reviewBody: The Mision San Javier is remote, beautiful and spiritual. It\'s 34 km off Mexico Rte 1 just as you exit Loreto. Pass Giganta mountain: gorgeous mountain scenery. Road is being patched in parts because of flood washouts but nothing to tough for our Toyota Corolla.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

192516220.name: So Worth Your Time
192516220.author: a TripAdvisor user
192516220.reviewBody: Our group had the rare honor of traveling to this mission far up into the hills. Getting there was no easy ride as the road had been washed out in many places necessitating our vehicles to drive through many running streams. We were greeted by the two town dogs with wagging tails who sometimes accompanied us on our walk through this historic village. The mission was sacred. Upon entering, one felt a spiritual presence. The surrounding beauty of hills, blooming flowers and ancient crooked olive trees is a scene I will not soon forget.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

192260840.name: Quite a place!
192260840.author: a TripAdvisor user
192260840.reviewBody: My wife and I rented a car in Loreto and took the road out to the mission.  It had a number of washouts that were being worked on but all in all not a problem driving out to it.  The Mission was built in the sixteen hundreds and was quite ornate for its time.  Especially the woodworking. There are trails that lead out behind the mission where you can see a 300 year old olive tree.  Very impressive.  The scenery around the mission was rugged and beautiful.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

191144755.name: The mission oasis
191144755.author: a TripAdvisor user
191144755.reviewBody: Keep: the mission and all its ancillaries. It\'s a magic place to reach on the wavy road, sometimes interrupted by stones and creeks.\nChange: a bit cleaner and better road indications. The place should be kept cleaner and the road signs to reach it are basically not existing. Even for some GPS it\'s challenging. Is it for purpose?;)

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

190719195.name: Ancient cathedral, lovely village
190719195.author: a TripAdvisor user
190719195.reviewBody:
We were driven there by Ivan, who works for El Tiburon Casitas.He is a wealth of information  and we were entertianed and enthralled all along the way. The amount of work that has been accomplished since the torrential rains is amazing.We felt the road was very safe. 
we like to learn the history of places we visit, and it was great to go with Ivan. At the restaurant, privately owned,  I had the most delicious burritos ever.
I find the owners/ managers always bring a little treat at the end of the meal. This time, we were given a small plate of  olives, grown by the owner, and delicious grapefruit, sweet lemons (?) 
The San Javier Mission even has a tiny graveyard out back, beautiful inside. I was shocked to see that some careless people had thrown cigarette butts inside the graveyard...no respect! We picked them up.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

190669691.name: The second mission on the El Camino Real
190669691.author: a TripAdvisor user
190669691.reviewBody: The mission is still in it\'s original form and quite lovely. Don\'t miss the 300 year old Olive tree that was planted when the mission was completed.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

190050448.name: Not much to do there...
190050448.author: a TripAdvisor user
190050448.reviewBody: If you don\'t take a paid tour - you won\'t get much out of this..!  we were lucky to \'find\' the olive tree out back \u2026 but thanks to Trip Advisor\u2026 we even knew it was there!

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

190044821.name: Good road -- excellent scenery
190044821.author: a TripAdvisor user
190044821.reviewBody: This place is probably the most interesting tourist draw in Loreto.  You drive south on the Transpeninsular and about 50 m south of the river crossing, take a right (west) on the only paved road that comes into the Transpeninsular.  There is no sign.  It is about 40 km to the mission.  The scenery is excellent.  The lunch places in San Francisco Javier are really good.  It is an amazing place.  Las Parras on the road in is also interesting.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

188228881.name: Great drive
188228881.author: a TripAdvisor user
188228881.reviewBody: The drive is worth it.  The road is paved 90% of the way.  The water, not too deep, runs across the road several times.  It was fun to see random live stock feeding along the road.  We enjoyed walking around the mission and envisioning folks from times past. Lots of fabulous doors to take pictures of.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

187446938.name: Great side trip from Loreto
187446938.author: a TripAdvisor user
187446938.reviewBody: We loved this little village of 200 with the oldest mission to explore.  It was amazing to imagine the Natives building this for the priest for whatever motivated them.  We thought it might have been for protection from other tribes.  But the drive to the mission is through beautiful desert.  The road has been fixed, at least temporarily, from the severe October storm.  It doesn\'t take long to get there and the photo opportunities are endless.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

187355144.name: The road is an adventure.
187355144.author: a TripAdvisor user
187355144.reviewBody: This was a lovely side trip.  Well worth your time.  The restaurant in town makes great enchiladas.  The road is not for the faint of heart.  All the rain this year has washed out significant portions there are several river crossings so you vehicle needs to have high clearance.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

186949499.name: Jewel of the South don\'t miss it!
186949499.author: a TripAdvisor user
186949499.reviewBody: What a pleasure to be able to view such a magnificent historic site that is as it has been for over 300 years. If you plan to visit Dec. 1,2 and 3 are the dates of the annual celebration.  We arrived  in Loreto on the last day so missed the festivities.  This was a disappointment. Don\'t miss taking a walk behind the mission to find the olive tree that is over 200 years old. It is magnificent. And don\'t forget to sign the guest book.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

184990101.name: Cute village; "exciting" drive
184990101.author: a TripAdvisor user
184990101.reviewBody: Beautiful small village way up in the hills west of Loreto.  The interior is getting whitewashed right now, so the altar is covered.  Went early on a Saturday morning, so the village was still waking up.\nThe drive up is not for the faint of heart currently; recent rains washed out significant parts of the road in may places, so take your time, be very watchful for the edge of the pavement, and go easy in the areas where a temporary dirt road has been cut; if you\'re not used to driving off road, take a tour or taxi.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

184924157.name: Worth the trip!
184924157.author: a TripAdvisor user
184924157.reviewBody: It\'s amazing to see a mission that is over 350 years old! The little town is quaint, the scenery beautiful, the olive tree astounding. The restaurant (Palapa Javier) is terrific. Have the burros, and DO Not miss the date bread at the restaurant.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

183773414.name: Beautiful Mission in the Mountains
183773414.author: a TripAdvisor user
183773414.reviewBody: I drove the 25 miles to San Javier before the new road was in place. It was very rocky and took about 1.25 hours to get to the town. The mission has been restored and is very nice nestled in the Sierra Gigante mountains. There is not much to do in the town but there are at lease 2 restaurants. The views are spectacular. Well worth the trip.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

183513414.name: Exciting Drive
183513414.author: a TripAdvisor user
183513414.reviewBody: The road has been washed out for a few years now and you have to drive through creeks and on some really rough road. You can probably make it in a two wheel drive, but should have high clearence. It is worth the drive.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

182148581.name: On the road to San Javier Mission.
182148581.author: a TripAdvisor user
182148581.reviewBody: The trip to the mission was half the fun in an ATV. Many parts of the road had been washed out and were patched up and just passable. The mission itself was awe inspiring. I felt that it was exactly as it was 300 years ago right down to the old wooden doors. Lit a candle, said some prayers and took a ton of pix. Was one of our highlights of the Loreto area for sure!!!

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

181475635.name: loretto mission
181475635.author: a TripAdvisor user
181475635.reviewBody: Mission is typical old Mexico, rustic outside and well kept inside, you do not need a lot of time to see but it is worth the time to visit, once there you are in the center of town so go enjoy.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

180355817.name: beautiful old cathedral
180355817.author: a TripAdvisor user
180355817.reviewBody: We went when empty and to the Sunday service. Loved hearing the children\'s choir singing on Sunday and seeing all the village people attending services.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

178176014.name: San Javier Mission
178176014.author: a TripAdvisor user
178176014.reviewBody: What an amazing place!  The caretaker took us to see the 300 year old olive tree behind the church.  The views on the drive from Loreto were beautiful -- even though we had to deal with a lot of washed out spots in the road.  We had a wonderful lunch in the \'town\' after touring the church and grounds.

175725965.name: Historic piece of our American history

175725965.reviewBody: The Mission at San Javier is in the mountains about 30 minutes of scenic driving from Loreto.  It was the second mission of the California Missions to be built by the Jesuits.  In nearly it\'s original form it is a piece of history not to be missed while in the area.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

173046794.name: Adventure
173046794.author: a TripAdvisor user
173046794.reviewBody: It is hard to believe that a Mission was built out there in the middle of the desert. The road to get there is long and curvy, washed out in several areas, undermined in a few, but well worth the trip. There are palm and fruit trees around the Mission and it is so peaceful. 170444789.author: a TripAdvisor user

166632442.name: Mission San Javier, worth the trip
166632442.author: a TripAdvisor user
166632442.reviewBody: It is an adventure to drive to the mission, the roads need some repair.  There are areas of dirt roads, so be prepared if you make the trip. 163890001.name: A great side trip in Loreto
163890001.author: a TripAdvisor user
163890001.reviewBody: We took a nice tour to the Mission. The ride up the mountain was spectacular, and the Mission was beautiful. We also toured the grounds behind, with the ancient olive trees and working ajido farms. Then a nice lunch before heading back to town.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

162111428.name: Excellent Culture Experience
162111428.author: a TripAdvisor user
162111428.reviewBody:
I would recommend this tour with Wild Loreto to anyone visiting the Loreto Area.  The drive from downtown Loreto to the Mission is fantastic, stopping at the Camino Real to see cave paintings and learning about the plants and wild life was extremely useful and interesting.  Our Second stop took us to a road side mission that was built 70 years ago.  The current owners of the farm and mission also take their goods to the market every Sunday.
Entering the San Javier Mission site was like going back in time, the cobble street lined with Adobe Houses with thatch roofs made the drive up to the mission authentic. 
After touring the mission our Guide Roberto took us on a walk about around the grounds, stopping at several of the fruit trees and picking the fruit for us to taste added to the overall experience.
Our tour ended with lunch at one of the three restaurants.  The food was excellent.

161845151.name: Well worth the trek
161845151.author: a TripAdvisor user
161845151.reviewBody: We stopped at several places along the way, and the Mission was a delighful place to see. The vistas along the way are simply fabulous!

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

161819574.name: Mission San Javier
161819574.author: a TripAdvisor user
161819574.reviewBody: Good trip - very interesting.  Roberto was knowledgeable and he and Fausto took care of us well.  Enjoyed the lunch at the only restaurant in this small town.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

161552266.name: Great scenery, charming town, nice photo op
161552266.author: a TripAdvisor user
161552266.reviewBody: We drove up to this oasis pueblo in our own vehicle from Loreto.  The trip is about 40 km and takes about an hour each way.  The road is mostly paved but portions of it are washed out or dirt and the drop offs over the side can be scary.  Do not attempt this at night.  The scenery is beautiful on the way up and the tiny town of San Javier picturesque - adobe houses with thatched roofs, cobblestone streets and the gracious old mission church (one of the best preserved in Baja and dating back to the early 1700s) - still in use on Thursdays, when a priest comes in from Loreto to say mass.  Since the Loreto area is desert, the sight of year-round water here is an absolute treat. There\'s not a lot to do in town as far as dining and shopping, but it is a nice day trip.  Clean public restrooms across from the church that you can use for a 5 peso fee. There are a few places selling some crafts, olives, cheese, jams etc.  Nice laid-back atmosphere and a glimpse of slow-paced rural Mexico, devoid of glitz and heavy-handed touristy aura.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

161194820.name: worth the trip!
161194820.author: a TripAdvisor user
161194820.reviewBody: We were going to drive there ourselves but decided to go with a guide, we were glad we did! Our guide, Oscar was GREAT! We stopped along the way many times, the cave paintings, the old fig tree growing out of a rock and the highlight was stopping at a families working ranch/house and learning about cheesemaking and tasting their delicious goat cheese! Yes, the road is really bad in many places but even I didn\'t freak out! And I was sooo glad we did go! The scenery is awesome! The Mission is beautiful, and the sense of history and sacredness you feel there is beautiful! The surrounding community gives you a feel of authentic Baja!

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

160912786.name: San Javier Mission With Wild Loreto
160912786.author: a TripAdvisor user
160912786.reviewBody: We took the tour to San Javier from our home base of Villa del Palmar Loreto. Our guide Roberto made the trip as enjoyable as possible while our driver Fausto skilfully navigated some rough roads washed out by last fall\'s destructive Hurricane Paul. Our first stop was at a wide place in the road featuring a variety of local flora, streams and two ancient rock paintings. We were advised to touch nothing, for example, a nearby hierba de flecha shrub, every part of which is poisonous! We continued on to the outskirts of a ranch, once owned by three maiden sisters buried in a family cemetery near a chapel open to the pilgrims who trek to San Javier. The mission itself, built by the Jesuits, and the surrounding village is quite lovely. How and why such a place was constructed is difficult for a person living in the 21st Century to fathom. The mission is still active in that on Thursdays, a priest travels to the village to conduct mass for local inhabitants. Roberto took us on a walking tour to show us the locally grown crops (onions, citrus, beans,  olives) and so we could see the oldest olive tree in the America\'s. It\'s a 300 year old monster, missing one major branch where some payoso backed a pickup into the tree. Later, we had lunch at what appears to be the only restaurant in town; we enjoyed the food. My husband sampled the locally made wine; it\'s a sweet uncorked red made from a cabernet grape. To the amusement of our fellow travelers he pronounced it "not complex" but bought a bottle anyway for 200 pesos. On the way out of the village, Roberto stopped at a small hotel, "Casa de Ana", at our request to pick up info-- we think it would be fun to return to the area on our own with friends for an overnight stay. Their handout describes the property as having "rustic style adobe bungalows" at 450 pesos per room. We were very pleased with the tour, and especially recommend it to those who have not had the opportunity to drive through the mountainous areas of Baja.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

159441783.name: Well worth the drive!
159441783.author: a TripAdvisor user

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

159193847.name: worth the drive
159193847.author: a TripAdvisor user
159193847.reviewBody: Up a recently paved road although some washouts, through interesting terrain - little streams and waterfalls along the way.  Lovely old mission in verdant valley - beautiful walk through the hundreds of years old olive orchard. Only one place open for food but not bad. Bought fresh peas and cookies from stand in front.

159091165.name: Oasis

158992982.name: Wild Loreto San Javier Mission tour
158992982.author: a TripAdvisor user
158992982.reviewBody: All we can say is AWESOME! Our tour guides Rammes Martinez & Omar Medina were great!! This is a must see!!! Rammes is so knowledgeable & friendly!! Come to Loreto to experience real Mexico!!!!

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

158867962.name: Long drive but cute town
158867962.author: a TripAdvisor user
158867962.reviewBody: This was an interesting day trip from Loreto. Cute mission town. Not much there except a  couple restaurants, a couple shops, and the mission. Not a "must" but something nice to do.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

158634417.name: Worth the trip into the mountains
158634417.author: a TripAdvisor user
158634417.reviewBody: The mission is outside of Loreto with the turnoff south of Loreto on BS Mexico Route 1. It is well worth the side trip into the mountains. The first part is a moderately steep windy paved road which sometimes gets washouts after heavy rain. This year the road is paved all the way to the mission, a big improvement from last year when about 50% was gravel. The mission is small but quite historic with a very nice gilded altar backdrop. The area immediately around the mission has small tiendas and restaurants as well as overnight accommodation. Tours can be arranged from Loreto or you can rent a car and drive there yourself. Certainly worth the drive and the visit. One of these days I will spend a night here, just for the peace and quiet. Allow about 50 mins each way from Loretto plus about 45 minutes to see the Mission area.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

158405917.name: Beautiful little town and mission
158405917.author: a TripAdvisor user
158405917.reviewBody: Well worth the road there.  Many interesting things to see along the way. I do wish there were more local foods, crafts for sale there though.  The farms around the mission are beautifully self sustained.

158389004.name: Mission San Javier

156539762.name: san javier mission is worth the drive.

156539762.reviewBody: awe-inspiring to think of the conditions the Jesuit priests and their native followers had to work under to construct such a beautiful mission.  a quaint little town that hasn\'t changed much in the past 100 plus years, judging from the pictures hung at the Palapa.

156207752.name: History and beauty

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

154662249.name: the mission and village.
154662249.author: a TripAdvisor user
154662249.reviewBody: Very interesting. There is a recent effort to make products in the village that people can buy to support the village residents.  Great idea. We did not buy anything because we could not take it back into the US and we were leaving the next day.  The mission is very pretty, very old.  Built in the 1700s.  The priests that lived and worked there did farming and their irrigation methods are still used today and the fields and crops that are there now are still the same ones that they did when the priests were there.  Residents of the village work the fields now.  Except for a very small part, the road going to the mission and village through the mountains is in pretty good shape.  I was surprised considering that a hurricane went through there a year ago and washed everything out.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

154480151.name: Excellent example of a working mission
154480151.author: a TripAdvisor user
154480151.reviewBody: The mission is well preserved and seeing it as a working farm using the original irrigation system, or at least part of it was very interesting. It is a beautiful site. The trip up into the mountains adds to the sense of place and what it means to live in Baja Cali.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

154110484.name: what a beautiful place!
154110484.author: a TripAdvisor user
154110484.reviewBody: What a great place to visit!  its a bit of a drive but it is worth it!  Very beautiful historic mission!  be sure to take a walk behind the mission and follow the paths to see the orchards the huge olive trees and farmland!

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

153727801.name: Nice ride into the rugged hills
153727801.author: a TripAdvisor user
153727801.reviewBody: The mission itself is not too much to talk about.  It\'s old, barely maintained yet still in use.\nBut the ride to it and the village around it give you a feel for Mexico rural life that you won\'t find in Cabo.  I thought it was a nice way to spend a day.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

152482283.name: Beautiful mission in the Giganta Sierra
152482283.author: a TripAdvisor user
152482283.reviewBody: We took a comfortable van ride into the mountain above Loreto and stopped to see cave paintings. Our guide, Said Orozco, was very knowledgeable about the area and plants and history. The mission is a beautiful oasis in the mountains untouched by time. The church serves the town of San Javier whose residents have been living there for generations. The townspeople farm and raise livestock. The church is built of stone, brought in from the surrounding areas. Walls are as much as seven feet thick, keeping the interior of the church cool during hot summers. The insides are decorated with Spanish and Italian art which is older than the building itself. The trip included lunch in the town. The view on the way back are just beautiful. An awesome trip.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

151669105.name: Worth the drive
151669105.author: a TripAdvisor user
151669105.reviewBody: The road to San Javier was almost washed out in several spots, with the pavement gone and in places undercut and caved in to reduce the road to one lane. Some of these spots are on arroyos so steep you wonder how on earth they are going to repair it. But the trip was worth it to see the old mission, cobblestone streets, etc. Be sure to check out the small building across from the cafe where local handicrafts are sold.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

151433851.name: Beautiful old mission, not too far away.
151433851.author: a TripAdvisor user
151433851.reviewBody:
Our group of 6 family adults booked this trip through our hotel, La Mision.  We were fortunate to have a local guide (I think his name was Jose), who spoke very good English, and a driver who was adept at avoiding washed away areas enroute.  There had been a big hurricane which passed through a few months prior, washing out many sections of roadway; perhaps there had been some repair, but one would want to drive this route only in daylight.  

Our guide stopped to show us some ancient rock paintings and a fig tree, on the shady side of a hillside, that had managed to survive by sending its roots deep into the rocks.   

There is a small village surrounding the old mission and lots of lovely old rock work.  The mission building itself is a beautiful example of the early missions built along the Pacific coast.

We felt this trip was well worthwhile, and we lucked out in having a knowledgable guide who spoke our language.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

151204700.name: Worth the trip
151204700.author: a TripAdvisor user
151204700.reviewBody: It\'s about 30 minutes away from Loreto. The drive was a bit dangerous because there were parts of the road that were completely washed out, but once you get there it is worth the trip. \nAlthough it is quite small and you are done visiting it quickly, it is  very nice to walk around the town, it is nice and very clean. There are good sweets and empanadas that you can enjoy while you visit.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

151091542.name: Don\'t miss this side trip
151091542.author: a TripAdvisor user
151091542.reviewBody: While some might skip this 1 hour drive up into the nearby mountains, don\'t miss it! The winding drive is beautiful, even with the road washouts from the winter rainstorms. San Javier sits in a small valley with huge mountains in the background. The Mission, built in 1699 is beautiful and the town so pretty and quiet. There is a lovely cafe just to the right of the church that serves simple good food.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

150600320.name: A must for Mission Trail buffs
150600320.author: a TripAdvisor user
150600320.reviewBody: I was excited to visit this mission, as it is the first in the Californias. It\'s set in the middle of nowhere in the mountains and I don\'t envy those who built the structure. While it\'s 20 miles from Loreto, the drive takes about an hour. The roads have improved tremendously, I\'ve been told, in the last year. It is pretty and quaint and a must if only for the historic value.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

150524663.name: Pass
150524663.author: a TripAdvisor user
150524663.reviewBody: We drove to San Javier on our own and, as we expected, the roads are driveable, but a bit sketchy in places.  When we finally got there, the church itself was not that remarkable, there was garbage everywhere and there is really nothing else to see.  There is only one restaurant near the church (and only bathroom).  In my opinion, it was a bit of a wasted morning, other than getting some pretty great pictures of a washed out road.  The church in Loreto was very similar in appearance without the drive.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

150381374.name: I gave it a poor rating because ........
150381374.author: a TripAdvisor user
150381374.reviewBody: I went at the wrong time, there was a gathering of many 1,000\'s of pilgrims and from what I could see it would have been worth the trip however I was put off by all the vendors selling everything from this to that. Mostly unlrelated to the Mission. I do understand the ways of the people but I think this went way too far. Having said that don\'t miss this one on a none pilgrimage weekend.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

150217604.name: Old Mission
150217604.author: a TripAdvisor user
150217604.reviewBody: Our guide, Nikki, with Desert and Sea, was very knowledgeable, took a detour to show us an impressive wild fig tree, told us all about the farmland as we hiked around the valley that the mission is in, explained the aqua duct gravity feed water system, told us so much history I can\'t remember it all, and of course, we toured the mission.  Had lunch afterwards at the restaurant up there and were able to sample sweet lemons, oranges, and olives, all from the valley.  Highly recommend this trip.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

149998748.name: A step back in time.
149998748.author: a TripAdvisor user
149998748.reviewBody: The road is quite interesting to say the least. We turned around when sections were missing. Hired a local who was fabulous. He took us off the beaten track and we never would have seen these things. They are working hard and placing the missing roads....

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

149798699.name: Amazing
149798699.author: a TripAdvisor user
149798699.reviewBody: If you like history, San Javier is a must-see.  From what I have read, it is the oldest mission that has not been substantially restored.  It is a beautiful drive up in the mountains and well worth the time.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

149134804.name: Treacherous roads to the Treasure of Baja
149134804.author: a TripAdvisor user
149134804.reviewBody: This mission is the oldest of all in BCS, every Christmas there is a huge pilgrimage to this location. The much of the road has been washed out or covered in land slides so you\'ll need a 4x4 and take your time and be safe!\n\nThe trip is well worth it though, I really love the stone architecture and reading about some of the history of the mission itself. Along the way there is a smaller church that leads to some really amazing cave paintings if you have the time (this requires a whole day).

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

147877294.name: The trip is better then the destination
147877294.author: a TripAdvisor user
147877294.reviewBody: Rough road to get there but was a fun adventure. The mission is poorly maintained. Coke cans and tomatoes were left at the "alters" The interior is poorly maintained. Shameful history. The surrounding town was desolate and a bit unnerving

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

147371010.name: A step back in time
147371010.author: a TripAdvisor user
147371010.reviewBody: The drive to get there still feels long, with curves and scenic views on all sides.  The Mission is history, , and the 300 year old olive and irrigation ditches are fascinating. For me, although it\'s changing, it is still a trip back in time, and the ranchers you meet there are real people; friendly and independent. Going there is always a special treat.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

146189315.name: Loreto Mission
146189315.author: a TripAdvisor user
146189315.reviewBody: Great history and lots of prayers have been requested on these sacred grounds.  Love the festival of the Virgen de Loreto held in September.  Brings back very special memories.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

144812449.name: Worth the drive
144812449.author: a TripAdvisor user
144812449.reviewBody: It was a nail biter of a drive to the Mission with the roads washed out in a lot of places but it was worth it. The views are spectacular. The mission was fascinating and very quaint.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

144791381.name: Do not miss the Mission  San Javier
144791381.author: a TripAdvisor user
144791381.reviewBody: Definitely need a vehicle, but worth the trip! Very historic and amazing the see what the priests did with irrigation and crop cultivation and the beautiful church.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

144509638.name: Amazing!!
144509638.author: a TripAdvisor user
144509638.reviewBody: The mission is incredibly beautiful silhouetted against the mountains.  Walk behind it to see some really old olive trees.  Also, there is a local olive processing plant right near the mission.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

140858925.name: historic mission
140858925.author: a TripAdvisor user
140858925.reviewBody: Beautiful scenic drive into the mountains, views back to the sea of Cortes.  Friendly locals.  Bring water/beer for the drive.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

140440953.name: Beautiful and historic!
140440953.author: a TripAdvisor user
140440953.reviewBody: It is a LONG drive, the first third is paved and has gorgeous scenery, then it turns into a dirt/rock road, which is rough and feels like it takes longer then you\'d think...but once you see the mission its all worth it! There was a little restaurant to eat at which was great too. Definitely a great experience!

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

139000051.name: Authentic small town up the Sierra.
139000051.author: a TripAdvisor user
139000051.reviewBody: The route to drive up there has gorgeous views, with a stream and painted caves along the way. The town has a main street with cobblestones and a few shops with local products. The church at the end is from the time of the Jesuits, behind it there is a nice private ranch with olive and fruit trees.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

138437450.name: In a Surreal setting worth the time to get there
138437450.author: a TripAdvisor user
138437450.reviewBody: Yes, the road is very curvy but it is so beautiful! We rented a car for a couple of days and think that this is a better way to see things  rather than taking tours with a lot of other people. We felt very safe driving and moving around. The people were very friendly.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

134939433.name: Beautiful but not worth it
134939433.author: a TripAdvisor user
134939433.reviewBody: $50 a head to take an hour ride up to see a church. Enough said.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

134937781.name: Nice historical landmark
134937781.author: a TripAdvisor user
134937781.reviewBody: The only part I didn\'t enjoy was the long windy drive getting there but at least there was only one road and it ended at the mission and the little villa around it. The last couple of kilometers was still being worked on to be paved since that portion was still dirt road. On the way there there is a turnout on the left side of the road which is an archaeological site where there are cave drawings. Coming back was more of an enjoyable drive since you could see the ocean in the distance getting closer.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

134099758.name: Mission San Javier
134099758.author: a TripAdvisor user
134099758.reviewBody: If you are in Loreto, Mexico and you want to see the real Mexican Baja and one of the best preserved examples of a 18th century Jesuit mission visit Mission San Javier. The present mission dates to 1758. A gilded baroque alterpiece, oil paintings, statues, crucifix, cemetary and the most beautiful Baja landscape surround the mission. Tours from Loreto are available or drive up yourself. It is an active church. A small restaurant (Palapa) and store are in the small village of San Javier. This village is a time capsule. On your way up stop at Cuevas Pintas to see cave paintings. It\'s well marked and paintings are on the rock walls that line the arroyo. The landscape in the Sierra la Giganta mountains will keep you camera busy.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

132349531.name: A Church worth seeing.
132349531.author: a TripAdvisor user
132349531.reviewBody: My husband hates looking at old buildings especially churches, but he really liked this little spot. The view of the church from looking down the boulevard with mountain in the background is worth the trip out. The drive up is very beautiful, paving is getting close to completion, just a few more kms to go. We saw wild goats, wild burrows, colorful birds, colorful lizards and many fruit trees including the 300 year old olive tree. The cave paintings were interesting but unfortunately they are starting to fade and fall apart. If you are in Loreto and looking for a tour that is not too expensive, this is worth a look.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

130988598.name: Day Trip
130988598.author: a TripAdvisor user
130988598.reviewBody: This is a must when in Loreto.  When there go to the back of the church and see the olive tree its over 300 years old.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo

129765052.name: Worth The Trip
129765052.author: a TripAdvisor user
129765052.reviewBody: We drove to San Javier and were very glad we chose to visit there. It is a 35 km drive each way in the mountains. The first 28 km are paved and it is a good but definitely not straight road. The remaining 5 km are currently under construction and it is a little hard to follow at times. The scenery enroute is very impressive and there a few places to stop and take photos. The mission buildings are very well preserved and we actually preferred the San Javier mission to the one in Loreto. The mission itself was started in 1699, just two years after Loreto. The building was completed in the mid 1700\'s. There is currently little in the way of services in San Javier.

itemReviewed.name: Mision San Francisco Javier de Vigge-Biaundo
